quiz.title: AP Physics C: Mechanics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 1, Quiz 3: Advanced Calculus in 1D Motion
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: The position of a particle is given by $x(t) = 2t^3 - 6t^2 + 10$. At what time $t$ is the acceleration of the particle zero?
A particle starts from rest ($v=0$ at $t=0$). Its acceleration is $a(t) = 4t + 1$. What is its velocity at $t = 2\text{ s}$?
The velocity of a particle is $v(t) = 3t^2 - 2$. If the particle is at $x = 5$ when $t = 0$, what is the position function $x(t)$?
questions.explanation: $x(t) = \int v(t) \, dt = \int (3t^2 - 2) \, dt = t^3 - 2t + C$. Using $x(0)=5$: $0^3 - 2(0) + C = 5 \Rightarrow C = 5$. Thus, $x(t) = t^3 - 2t + 5$.

questions.question: A particle moves with a velocity $v(t) = 2t^3$. What is the average acceleration from $t = 1\text{ s}$ to $t = 3\text{ s}$?
questions.explanation: Average acceleration = $\frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t}$. $v(3) = 2(27) = 54\text{ m/s}$, $v(1) = 2(1) = 2\text{ m/s}$. $\Delta v = 54 - 2 = 52\text{ m/s}$, $\Delta t = 3 - 1 = 2\text{ s}$. $a_{avg} = 52 / 2 = 26\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A particle's velocity is $v(t) = 6 - 3t$. What is the total distance traveled from $t = 0$ to $t = 3\text{ s}$?
questions.explanation: Particle stops when $v=0$: $6 - 3t = 0 \Rightarrow t=2\text{ s}$. Displacement from $0$ to $2$: $\int_0^2 (6-3t) dt = [6t - 1.5t^2]_0^2 = (12 - 6) = 6\text{ m}$. Displacement from $2$ to $3$: $\int_2^3 (6-3t) dt = [6t - 1.5t^2]_2^3 = (18-13.5) - (12-6) = 4.5 - 6 = -1.5\text{ m}$. Total distance = $|6| + |-1.5| = 7.5\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A particleâ€™s position is $x(t) = 12t - t^3$. What is the particle's maximum velocity for $t \geq 0$?
questions.explanation: $v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt} = 12 - 3t^2$. This is a downward-opening parabola in $t$ with maximum at $t=0$. $v(0) = 12 - 0 = 12\text{ m/s}$. For $t>0$, velocity decreases.

questions.question: If $v(x) = \sqrt{2gx}$, what is the acceleration $a$ of the particle? (Use $a = v \frac{dv}{dx}$)
An object's position is $x(t) = At^2 - Bt^3$ (where $A, B > 0$). At what time $t$ does the acceleration change from positive to negative?
The acceleration of a particle is $a(t) = \sin(t)$. If $v(0) = 0$, what is the velocity at $t = \pi$?
questions.explanation: $v(t) = \int a(t) \, dt = \int \sin(t) \, dt = -\cos(t) + C$. Using $v(0)=0$: $-\cos(0) + C = 0 \Rightarrow -1 + C = 0 \Rightarrow C=1$. Thus $v(t) = -\cos(t) + 1$. At $t=\pi$: $v(\pi) = -\cos(\pi) + 1 = -(-1) + 1 = 1 + 1 = 2\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A particle moves such that $x(t) = \sum_{n=0}^2 t^n = 1 + t + t^2$. What is its acceleration at $t = 5\text{ s}$?
questions.explanation: $x(t) = 1 + t + t^2$. Velocity $v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt} = 1 + 2t$. Acceleration $a(t) = \frac{dv}{dt} = 2$, which is constant. Therefore, at $t=5$, $a = 2\text{ m/s}^2$.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered advanced calculus applications in 1D motion, including position-dependent acceleration, sign changes, and series representations.
scoreMessages.70: Very strong performance. Review: the chain rule for acceleration ($a = v\,dv/dx$), finding inflection points in acceleration, and calculating total distance with direction changes.
scoreMessages.50: Good foundation. Focus on: finding acceleration from position, integrating acceleration with initial conditions, applying the average acceleration formula, and interpreting velocity-time graphs.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the core calculus operations: $v = dx/dt$, $a = dv/dt$, and practice integrating polynomials and trigonometric functions with initial conditions.
